conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light. The shape and size of the shadow depend on the shape of the object and the position of the light source.
The size of the shadow is influenced by the distance between the object and the light source. The closer the light source is to the object, the larger the shadow.
The shadows A, B, C, and D are currently cast behind the objects, indicating that the light source is positioned in front of the objects.

premise: When the light source moves forward, it gets closer to the objects.
conclusion: As the light source moves forward, the angle of light rays hitting the objects changes, causing the shadows to shift.

premise: As the light source moves forward, the angle of light rays hitting the objects changes, causing the shadows to shift.
conclusion: The shadows will move closer to the objects. This is because the light rays will be more perpendicular to the ground, reducing the distance between the object and the shadow.

premise: When the light source moves forward, it gets closer to the objects.
conclusion: The shadows will become smaller. This is due to the light source being closer to the objects, which reduces the spread of light rays and thus the size of the shadow.

premise: The shadows will move closer to the objects. The shadows will become smaller.
conclusion: When the light source moves forward above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to the objects and become smaller.
